abstract: On Wednesday, the California start-up will debut its utility, which it says will produce cleaner and cheaper electricity.
snippet: On Wednesday, the California start-up will debut its utility, which it says will produce cleaner and cheaper electricity.
lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  A Silicon Valley company is claiming a breakthrough in a decades-old quest to develop fuel cells that can supply affordable and relatively clean electricity. Google, Bank of America, Wal-Mart and other large corporations have been testing the devices, which will be formally introduced on Wednesday.

headline.main: Bloom Energy Claims a New Fuel Cell Technology
headline.print_headline: Start-Up Asserts Its Fuel Cell Can Lower Cost of Electricity

abstract: Among the accusations is one that says the company plays down certain sites in its search results.
snippet: Among the accusations is one that says the company plays down certain sites in its search results.
lead_paragraph: Google faces European antitrust scrutiny after three companies filed complaints about what they consider unfair competition.

headline.main: New Complaints Filed Against Google in Europe
headline.print_headline: New Complaints Filed Against Google in Europe

abstract: Bloom Energy, which has raised about $400 million from investors, is claiming a breakthrough in a decades-old quest to develop fuel cells that can supply affordable and relatively clean electricity, The New York Times reported.
snippet: Bloom Energy, which has raised about $400 million from investors, is claiming a breakthrough in a decades-old quest to develop fuel cells that can supply affordable and relatively clean electricity, The New York Times reported.
lead_paragraph: A Silicon Valley company is claiming a breakthrough in a decades-old quest to develop fuel cells that can supply affordable and relatively clean electricity. Google, Bank of America, Wal-Mart and other large corporations have been testing the devices, which will be formally introduced on Wednesday.

abstract: Intel and 24 venture capital firms said Tuesday that they planned to invest $3.5 billion in American start-ups over the next two years in an effort to keep America competitive in technology education and innovation, The New York Times reported.
snippet: Intel and 24 venture capital firms said Tuesday that they planned to invest $3.5 billion in American start-ups over the next two years in an effort to keep America competitive in technology education and innovation, The New York Times reported.
lead_paragraph: Technologists have been worrying aloud for years that America is losing its competitive edge as other countries invest more heavily in technology education and innovation.

headline.main: A $3.5 Billion Effort Aims to Help Tech Start-Ups

abstract: Other items in our technology news roundup include a European antitrust inquiry into Google and a look at a new type of augmented reality technology.
snippet: Other items in our technology news roundup include a European antitrust inquiry into Google and a look at a new type of augmented reality technology.

headline.main: Bits Scan: Apple TV, an Improved Xbox and a Week Without Google

abstract: Start-up Bloom Energy unveils its energy servers, which use solid oxide fuel cells to generate electricity at low cost and with fewer greenhouse gas emissions.
snippet: Start-up Bloom Energy unveils its energy servers, which use solid oxide fuel cells to generate electricity at low cost and with fewer greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: Our colleague Todd Woody on the Green Inc. blog has an interesting blog post about Bloom Energy, a secretive fuel-cell start-up that was also the subject of an article Wednesday in The New York Times.

headline.main: A Maker of Fuel Cells Blooms in California
